doc.title: CIEN Earnings Preview & Model and Read-throughs
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Ciena Corporation CIEN Earnings Preview Model and Read-throughsCiena Corporation CIEN Earnings Preview Model and Read-th_2025-08-28

passages.text: Webscale outperformance and Pluggable acceleration well under way and should continue to be highlights for the Q, along with expected 2H Routing & Switching recovery. We look for commentary around the company's DCI opportunity and ultimate entry inside the data center.

CIEN Earnings (09/04). CIEN is expected to report FQ3 earnings pre- market on Thursday, September 4. We model revenues/EPS of \(\) 1,170M/\(\) 0.51\(for the Jul - Q and\) \ \(1,211M /\) 0.63 for the Oct - Q. Our estimates are roughly in line with the Street for both Qs. Cloud strength sustained with the vertical growing almost 90% y/y last Q (we estimate almost 50% y/y growth for FY) and management on track to see cloud orders double y/y in FY25. Last Q management remarked on a step change in demand from Cloud Providers - not just in terms of applications but also in terms of the number of cloud provider customers. Continued telco recovery along with MOFN ops also contributed to the beat last Q, and Routing & Switching strength expected in 2H as 1H order volume converts into revenue. We continue to look for more details around how CIEN is planning to play in the datacenter with its interconnect portfolio. Additionally, we look for updates on the pluggables business, and if there's upside to current FY forecast given (for revenue to at least double this FY vs FY24).

Despite lift in FY top- line guidance last Q, management maintained its long- term guide of 8- 11% top- line growth on average in FY25- 27. However, we are currently tracking above that target, and we expect management to likely revise the target by FY end. Tariff impacts remain minimal ( \(\sim\) 10M/Q) impacts to cost and incorporated into the updated guide. Recall, CIEN's supply chain is across Mexico, Thailand, Canada, and India with concentrations in Mexico and Thailand. We believe the majority of products shipped from Mexico and Canada are USMCA compliant.

Read- throughs from peers, suppliers, and customers across the optical arena are positive to neutral for CIEN. We expect the cloud business to remain strong, and believe the telco recovery is well under way.

- Lumenium. Optical component vendor Lumentum (LITE, covered by Tom O'Malley) no longer classifies revenue under a telco sub-segment, though management mentioned datacom is running ahead of telecom due to supply constraints on telco side, not demand related. Management highlighted the overall demand is coming from hypers, and that even though the customers are traditional telco customers, the source of demand is coming from the

IT Hardware and Communications Equipment
Potential Upside/Downside
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
cloud. Additionally, commentary on the rapid growth of the ZR market. The telco business and ZR growth dynamics remain in line with CIEN commentary.

- Cloud players. Last Q, cloud player GOOGL (covered by Ross Sandler) lifted FY capex guidance to \(\sim\) \$85Bn (previously \(\sim\) \$75Bn) and MSFT (covered by Raimo Lenschow) reiterated capex guidance. GOOGL's FY26 capex guidance lift represents 62% growth off of FY24 levels. MSFT continued to expect capex in FY26 to grow but at a lower rate than FY25. Both companies mentioned investment in technical infrastructure/Cloud and AI-related spend, which we view as a positive for CIEN, given exposure to DCI. We continue to expect cloud strength for CIEN in FY25 (although acknowledge revenue could be lumpy). Other hyperscalers are also adding to growth.
FIGURE 1. Estimated Cloud Capex Spend
Note: Calendarized Data; AMZN, GOOGL, META covered by Barclays analyst Ross Sandler; MSFT, ORCL covered by Barclays analyst Raimo Lenschow Source: Company Documents, Barclays Research Estimates.

- Carriers. Verizon and AT&T (both covered by Kannan Venkateshwar) maintained and lifted their FY capex guidance, respectively, last Q. We see a mostly neutral read from these capex guides, given the continued recovery in telco spend this year has already been well telegraphed across the industry.

- Nokia. Nokia (NOK, covered by Simon Coles), a competitor to CIEN in optical transport, provided commentary on its latest earnings call that the combined Optical Networks business (with Infinera acquisition) continues to see strong demand with book-to-bill >1. However, management did highlight growth was tempered somewhat due to supply constraints but these supply issues are expected to improve in 2H. The company continues to expect its acquisition of Infinera will help NOK gain more of a footprint within the AI and cloud space.

- Cloud strength sustainability. Cloud continues to drive the outperformance and we expect the vertical to continue to drive upside into FY end. The segment was \(\sim 38\%\) of total revenue last Q with three of the five top customers in the Q cloud providers. We look for updates on the breadth and scope of cloud applications and customers, and order momentum.

- Service provider recovery momentum. Management highlighted several new customer wins in both the Americas and International regions last Q, as SPs have had several Qs of improving trends. Momentum is driven by new fiber builds, as well as MOFN. Management highlighted they also achieved an all-time record on MOFN activity in 1HF25. We look for updates around SP recovery, MOFN activity, and order momentum. Recall, roughly 10-15% of Telco revenue is actually MOFN-related, and management has said they could see this seeing 10-20% over the next 18 months. We believe this business is skewing historical volatility and visibility into revenue linearity. Although we view the growing share of cloud revenue as a positive for the business, we expect it could increase overall share volatility given the vertical's lumpy revenue.

- Pluggables. Pluggable revenue is currently tracking ahead of guidance for revenue of at least \(\sim\)150M this FY, and last Q additional cloud providers contributed to volume in the business (previously it was just one CP driving material volumes). We look for updates around deployments of 800G pluggables in 2HCY25, as well as color around revenue cadence and potential seasonality in the business. Though pluggables are currently a margin drag, ramps and newer products (WaveLogic 6 Nano and 800G ZR) are expected to improve margin performance.

- Routing & Switching. Routing & Switching business came in below estimates last Q though we expect 2H strength as 1H order volume converts to revenue. Last Q management noted that Routing & Switching orders in 1H were \(>75\%\) of total orders last year. We look for updates around the business and order momentum in the Q.

- Margins. Margins disappointed in the Q given product mix (heavy RLS and pluggables), and management revised down the GM guide. Heavy line shipments coupled with higher pluggable volumes brought down GMs in the Q and are expected to suppress FQ3 margin upside as well (though we expect slight improvement into FQ4). Despite the margin guide down management remains on track to achieve 15-16% OM by FY27. The next generation of pluggables, along with capacity adds next FY, should improve margin performance beginning 4FQ25 into FY26 vs FY25.

- Interconnect opportunity. Though management has yet to decide on which paths they would pursue inside the DC, the company does have a new coherent lite solution. This product has a materially different competitive landscape than its optical systems business. We look for additional color on management's opportunity set and plans to pursue inside the DC opportunities.
Barclays | Ciena Corporation
**CIEN Model-6/05/25**

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
**Neutral** - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
**Negative** - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: Our price target of \(\) 102\(reflects a P/E multiple of\) 22x \(our FY27 EPS estimate of\) \ \(4.65\) , a premium to the 2- year average that we believe is justified based on expected high- double- digit EPS growth in FY26e and FY27e.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: 1) Competition. The optical space is very competitive given high growth relative to other networking segments. 2) Volatility. Ciena's business with Telcos has consistently been lumpy, and Cloud players could become more volatile. 3) Vertical integration. Cloud vendors like to vertically integrate, though efforts to do so in optical have stalled.

The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist.
